reviewText: These movies are a looking glass into the past!  Not just the story itself, but the stars, the acting ability shown in the times that they were made!  They are FABULOUS!  I purcased this collection some years ago directly from MILL CREEK on a (Believe It Or Not) $10. for ANY 50 pack!  I also own the 250 Pack Western Collection that Most of the Mill Creek Western Packs are made from.  Whatever Collection you own, I can only hope that you enjoy it as much as we do!  The movies vary in quality, acting ability, and that really does not matter real! y.  I enjoy watching them ALL, just as they are.  I am looking forward to getting "Cowboys and Bandits" Soon!  I am glad that AMAZON carries these Fabulous Collections.  By the way, None of these movies are included in the Giant WESTERN 250 Collection.  If you love Westerns, you'll LOVE these Movies TOO!

As with all Millcreek 50 packs some of the movies will have picture quality that is not perfect. However with so many movies that are not available anywhere else the set is still excellent value for the price.

The Way West 50 Movie Pack

Western movies were very popular in theaters from the 1930s to the 1940s, and on television in the 1950s and 1960s. Most people over fifty remember them. Younger people may also find them entertaining and educational. They had a message: those who do right win in the end. These movies defended small ranchers against the big landowners who wanted their lands. Others defended people against criminal gangs with "collective security". The right to keep and bear arms was well-recognized. Small movie studios were threatened by big movie studios with their cartel of theaters. Was it changing tastes or economics that caused their decline? Few people under fifty have ever seen horses used to work the land. Many were set in modern times and showed telephones, radios, and automobiles.

The newer westerns in the 1950s changed to personal conflicts from property conflicts. "High Noon" was an example of personal conflicts (with a hint of business conflicts). One movie noted how an increase in settlers disadvantaged cattle men since they could no longer graze their cattle on publicly owned range land. Government land were given to homesteaders, people who would earn the land by working and developing it. Laura Ingalls Wilder's books told about homesteading on the prairie and pioneer life on the frontier. Building a railroad into Texas ended the long cattle drives to the cow towns of Kansas. Store owners did more business with 500 families living year around than from 1,000 transient cowboys.

These movies were popular before big corporations began to put small owner-operated stores and farms out of business. One way was to cut off small business owners from wholesale distributors. If banks "red-lined" small businesses they could not get the loans needed for running their business. There were no government loans for farmers and ranchers then. Many of these films were produced by small studios who operated on a low budget. Later they were shown on television during the 1950s to fill up their broadcast schedule (the way some older TV shows are recycled today).

These western films had very little padding and there is more action than in some longer big studio productions. Some have songs and dances for entertainment. The stars are: Roy Rogers, Johnny Mack Brown, Buster Crabbe, James Newill, George O'Brien, Tex Ritter, Bob Steele and many others who are little remembered today. Some were real cowboys (Tim McCoy, Hoot Gibson) or rodeo riders (Ken Maynard). The formula of the "Three Mesquiteers" seems to have inspired the "Range Busters" and the "Rough Riders" (they were undercover investigators who fought gangs of criminals). The titles on each of the twelve single-sided DVDs follow.

01  Hands Across the Border (1944), Arizona Gunfighter (1937), Hittin' the Trail (1937), Come On, Cowboys (1937).
02  Law of the West (1932), Wagon Trail (1935), Brand of the Outlaws (1936), The Cheyenne Kid (1940).
03  The Border Menace (1932), Between Fighting Men (1932), Oklahoma Terror (1939), Lost Ranch (1937).
04  Arizona Round-Up (1942), Blazing Justice (1936), Brothers of the West (1937), Across the Plains (1939).
05  Cavalry (1936), Frontier Days (1934), When a Man Rides Alone (1933), The Montana Kid (1931).
06  Border Caballero (1936), Riders of the Rockies (1937), The Utah Trail (1938), Honor of the Range (1934).
07  Whistlin' Dan (1932), The Rider of the Law (1935), The Two Gun Man (1931), Texas Buddies (1932).
08  Idaho Kid (1936), Alias - The Bad Man (1931), Sunset Range (1935), Border Phantom (1937).
09  Ambush Valley (1936), Northwest Trail (1945), Bullets and Saddles (1943), Boss of Rawhide (1944).
10 Border Vengeance (1935), Law and Lawless (1932), No Man's Range (1935), Border Devils (1932).
11  Deadwood Pass (1933), Cowboy Holiday (1934), Hidden Valley (1932), Battles of Chief Pontiac (1952), Gun Lords of Stirrup Basin (1937).
12  Fugitive of the Plains (1943), Rogue of the Range (1936), Guns in the Dark (1937), Buffalo Bill in Tomahawk Territory (1952), Boot Hill Bandits (1942).

If you are a cowboy/western fan like me this is the movie package for you. This is a very good reproduction of some westerns of the 30's and 40's.  The actor's were for the most part real cowboys and it makes the movies very authentic.
I love these old Westerns, you can't beat the price for this collection. I'm looking to buy more of the same.
As a child of the 40's, western movies were the pastime of choice. This an opportunity to see some of them again.

The contents of MILL CREEK ENTERTAINMENT's THE WAY WEST 50 MOVIE PACK and FRONTIER JUSTICE 50 MOVIE PACK make up their GUNS OF THE WEST 100 MOVIE PACK (it's the one that I bought!). Unlike previous MCE and TREELINE boxes which consisted of flip-discs, their movies are now issued on single-side, dual layer DVDs. Transfer quality of these unrestored films depends entirely on source material. None are pristine studio quality but rarely are they so bad as to be unviewable. Certainly, the price is right for such a large offering of less-common works. There's genuine obscurities among these vintage 1930s and 40s programmers as well as old faves like Bob Steele, Harry Carey, the Texas Rangers, Crash Corrigan, Tex Ritter, Hoot Gibson and Roy Rogers. Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 imdb viewer poll ratings. I doubt that many classic western fans would pre-order this pack without knowing what's in it.  Would someone in the know please list the titles in this package?  It would be greatly appreciated by many of us who may want to make a purchase.  Thank you!  My four star rating is for Mill Creek Entertainment in general.
